caption:
The photograph depicts a close-up view of a cluster of evergreen needles, heavily adorned with water droplets. The needles, appearing primarily green, are densely packed, and their arrangement suggests they might be part of a pine or fir tree. Each needle is thin and elongated, with sharp tips, and they collectively create a somewhat chaotic yet natural pattern.

The droplets of water magnificently cling to the needles, varying significantly in size; some are small, speck-like, while others are larger and spherically shaped, capturing reflections and perhaps bits of the surrounding environment within them. These droplets highlight the texture of the needles, enhancing their glossy surface and the water's surface tension properties.

Positioned centrally and slightly towards the bottom of the frame is a cone or bud, perhaps indicating new growth on the tree. This cone is compact and appears to be shielded by the surrounding needles. It is yellowish-green in color, adding a slight contrast to the predominately dark green tones of the image. 

Overall, the composition focuses on capturing the intricate details and the interplay of light and water on the plant, conveying a sense of freshness and tranquility. It's a serene yet dynamic snapshot of nature, emphasizing textures, patterns, and the small-scale wonders of the natural world.
title: Close-up of new growth on a hemlock branch. Timberland on Vancouver Island, British Columbia. Near Port Alberni, British Columbia, Canada. From the Environmental Protection Agency's DOCUMERICA collection, "In Praise of Forests". For additional images see fiche #s 209, 210, 211, 212, and 213. ENTHEOS. Summer, 1974.
